div.class: post-1052 post type-post hentry category-suggests category-travel category-uncategorized tag-clothes tag-six-minute-style tag-travel tag-wsj

a.title: Permanent Link to A tote, a jumpsuit and an overpriced prescription for travel. Taking the WSJ to task.

h2.a: A tote, a jumpsuit and an overpriced prescription for travel. Taking the WSJ to task.

div.p: Got six grand to spend on your vacation wardrobe? Me neither. Which is why I have to take the Wall Street Journal to task. Over the weekend, I read an article titled, “What to Wear Where” in the newspaper’s Off Duty section. It’s a full-page spread laying out what to pack when traveling to Africa, Switzerland (for a quick ski weekend, no less), the Caribbean, or Hawaii. To further the fun, the piece includes images of celebrities in said destinations, dressed exactly as we should dress should we go. Oh to live the life of a celebrity. If you’re spending a cool 6k on clothes, what the heck are you spending on the trip?

I know publications create these lists to give us mere mortals a glimpse of some far off, fantasy lifestyle that we most likely will never achieve (and perhaps to boost ad revenues). But would it kill them to toss a few affordable options into the mix?

Honestly, if I had six thousand dollars kicking around, I wouldn’t spend it on clothes and accessories (a $495 tote bag?). I’d spend it on airline tickets to Buenos Aries, Morocco or some other far flung destination. There, I’d splurge on local cuisine, a fantastic massage and a couple of killer adventures. And, yes, I might want to purchase a few new pieces to fill out my suitcase, but I doubt I’d drop $900 for a belt to wear with my swimsuit (seriously?).

I’m sure there are WSJ readers ordering the suggested $800 winter boots right now, but I’m also willing to bet there are readers like me, eager to see some realistic (read: bargain priced) alternatives. After all, aren’t we in a depression/recession/economic funk?

I’m going to spend some time this week pulling together alternatives. Until then, here are a few to get you started. And, on a side note, a $2,200 jumpsuit is ridiculous not only because of the price, but because it’s a jumpsuit. It was cheesy then; it’s cheesy now. Some things are simply meant to fade from memory…

p.strong: The SMS List – What to Wear Without Breaking the Travel Budget

div.p: Athleta Swimsuits. I love the swimsuits from Athleta. They’re designed for action, so they fit well and stay put. Plus their super cute. Tops and bottoms are sold separately, so a good fit is pretty much guaranteed. Most pieces under $75. http://athleta.gap.com/browse/category.do?cid=46658
Still at Athleta, this dress is adorable and at just at $89, it feels like a steal. Roll it up, pack it and go. No wrinkles, no hassles, no $415 price tag.

You’re loving the retro, Hollywood feel of the WSJ piece, but not the bottom line, right? No worries. Boden has the perfect little tunic that will have you feeling every bit the1960s starlet. Simply tie a scarf around your head and add some Jackie O shades and you’re good to go. $88

Need some fun, kicky sneakers that will work with shorts and a skirt? Check out the affordable, colorful selection from Gola. I picked up a pair of the Quotas in orange when in Los Angeles this fall. They’re a fresh and flirty take on the usual rubber-soled shoe. $39 to $55
Jan 10, 2012 | Categories: Six Minute Style Suggests, Travel, Uncategorized | Tags: clothes, Six Minute Style, Travel, WSJ | Leave A Comment »

div.class: post-264 post type-post hentry category-showtale category-suggests tag-chick-flick tag-movie-review tag-sandra-bullock tag-the-proposal

a.title: Permanent Link to Rent This – The Proposal

div.p: First things first –this is a chick flick. A formulaic grab-the-box-of-tissues sort of film designed for a very specific demographic – women like me. And that’s okay. The thing to remember when watching this sort of film is that it won’t change your life or solve all your problems or leave you with some deep, soul-affirming message about the point of it all.

The Proposal is the kind of film you watch when you need to watch something soft and warm and cuddly and don’t have a cute, little lab puppy kicking around. The kind of film you zone out to while wearing your comfy pajamas (nothing sexy here), and sipping a nice glass of red wine. Ideally, your husband (if he’s anything like mine and needs to continually express his film critic opinions) is out, maybe at hockey or baseball or some other manly sort of sporting thing.

So, do I recommend the film? Actually, I do. I laughed. I cried. I ate a lot of M&MS. It’s cute. Now cute may not be what the director or writer or producer was aiming for when creating it, but cute is what they got. I had a nice, relaxing evening with no distractions. And what’s so bad about that? Could I get all film school-y here and mention the lack of a real antagonist or dissect the too-easily-resolved character arcs or question the reality/legality/probability of the plot line? Sure. But why? There was wine and chocolate and warm, fuzzy socks and a shirtless Ryan Reynolds. Which leads to the best parts of the film. The actors.
Ryan Reynolds is charming. And cute. And funny. He’s very likeable and looks great sans clothes. He and Bullock have nice chemistry. Did I mention he’s cute?
Sandra Bullock is Sandra Bullock. I didn’t buy her take as the high-powered-NYC-tough-as-nails-editor (big shoes to fill since Meryl Streep’s mesmerizing performance in “the Devil Wears Prada”), but found her quite charming and approachable once in Alaska (this will make sense once watching the film).
Craig T. Nelson. Remember Coach? Who doesn’t love Coach? The guy can rock a sweater vest like nobody’s business.
Betty White. If for no other reason, watch this film to see the glorious Betty White in action. She’s a freaking hoot.
I say rent it, watch it, enjoy it. There’s a reason chick flicks are always in style.
May 03, 2010 | Categories: Show & Tale, Six Minute Style Suggests | Tags: chick flick, movie review, Sandra Bullock, The Proposal | 3 Comments »

Links
Press Room

div.p:
Tell us what you’re interested in. More crafts? Easy recipes? Gift ideas? Maybe you’re planning a trip to a new destination and want some cool travel tips. Let us know.
In the coming months, we’ll be exploring Seattle and Venice, Italy, cooking up game menu items (think elk and bison) with the experts in Montana and steaming and eating lobster, fresh off the boat, in Maine. Stay tuned.
